Description: Rim sherd of South Ionian pottery cup with everted rim; interior: narrow reserved band at top of rim, glazed black below; top of lip glazed; exterior: lip reserved; inscription on exterior.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2
Curator's comments: The lack of diagnostic features makes it very difficult to determine from which type of South Ionian cups with everted rims the cup belongs. The incomplete rim suggests that it may have belonged to either a Type 9A cup, which had a short rim or possibly a Type 9B cup with a longer rim. Type 9A and Type 9B cups closely follow the shape and decoration of the Attic Plain Komast cups. These cups coincide with Petrie’s class L1 (Petrie 1886, 18) and Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type IX (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116), and Vallet and Villard’s Ionian Cup Type B2 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus, the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra, and at the site of Megara Hyblaea on Sicily. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.515) (Phase 3)
